Author: cilippofilia
Content: Hello guys! My name is Filippo and  I went back to study SwiftUI after taking a gap year. Is there any sort of framework I can implement to take full advantages of both swift and Cartesi?

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
Hey @cilippofilia! Welcome! 
In theory, you can develop front-end in any language including SwiftUI. The back-end logic however runs inside the Cartesi Machine, our VM based on RISC-V architecture. Hence, it is important to know that the language in question can be cross-compiled to RISC-V. It seems that it can be pulled off with Swift but not going to be an easy path!

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
üëã ***Hello! Glad to see you here!***

*Not sure where to begin your Cartesi Development journey? Check* https://cartesi.io/en/docs/build-dapps/overview/ *to get started.*

This channel is meant to ease your beginner journey. Ask doubts/questions, connect with other fellow developers, get guidance from our team, pioneers and other devs. And, of course, have fun!

*Let's push the boundaries together!* üöÄ

Author: lukabloomrox
Content: Hello, first day on this server.  Can somebody help me compare/contrast Blockchain OS with Radix DLT ecosystem?  I'm trying to figure out where this project sits in the grand scheme.  Thanks.  Please note: Radix is a Distributed Ledger technology, not technically a blockchain technology, but does support EVM through the Notoros project.

Author: lukabloomrox
Content: Also, there is an omission on the https://cartesi.io Technological Comparison page, EVM languages also include the Python-based Vyper language.

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
Hello and welcome @LukaBloomRox! As I gather from Radix's official site, it seems a base layer aiming to simplify building dapps around DeFi use-cases with a new high-level language based on Rust. I'm sure there are nuances to it that requires more research. 
Our goal on the other hand is to provide a scalable rollups framework that uses underlying base layer blockchain for dispute resolution. We let developers pick the language of their choice and let their imagination run wild on use-cases/possibilities. Our linux enabled VM - the Cartesi Machine makes this possible.

Author: riseandshaheen
Content: Yes, Vyper does work with EVM. The message we're trying to convey is the flexibility you get when running DApps on a linux runtime.

Author: divesh
Content: Is it possible to build native android applications using CTSI APIs ?

Author: divesh
Content: Or ... Is it on the roadmap?

Author: riseandshaheen
Content: Hello Divesh! The front-end interacts with backend via simple http API calls but this would require a good developer tooling for mobile DApps. It's not in our current roadmap but this is something we encourage our community members to contribute. We're here to support you! üôÇ

Author: carlofragni
Content: You can. You just need to use a web3 client of your choice, a graphql client of your choice and a HTTP client of your choice to interact with the interfaces of your DApp backend

Content:
Hi, I‚Äôm trying to deploy a custom DApp in Goerli following the instructions of the Readme.md file that comes inside the folder created by ./create-dapp.sh. I managed to build the backend machine and to send the deployment transaction. Now, when I start the node running the command from
`DAPP_NAME=Pipo-dapp docker compose -f ./docker-compose-testnet.yml -f ./docker-compose.override.yml up` , I can‚Äôt get it to finish setting up everything that I think it should do. That is, get a similar response to what I was getting when running an example dapp like echo-python. In my case, the `concurrent call in session` error keeps appearing. This is what I get in the log of the command that starts the node:

````
pipo-dapp-rollups_dispatcher-1      | Error: `start_session` request failed
pipo-dapp-rollups_dispatcher-1      | 
pipo-dapp-rollups_dispatcher-1      | Caused by:
pipo-dapp-rollups_dispatcher-1      |     status: DeadlineExceeded, message: "Deadline Exceeded", details: [], metadata: MetadataMap { headers: {"content-type": "application/grpc"} }
pipo-dapp-rollups_dispatcher-1 exited with code 1
```
````
pipo-dapp-rollups_indexer-1         |  INFO indexer::data_service: Connecting for sync to server manager http://server_manager:5001
pipo-dapp-rollups_indexer-1         |  INFO indexer::data_service: Trying to sync epoch status from server manager...
pipo-dapp-rollups_indexer-1         |  INFO rollups_data::database: Trying to connect to database postgresql://postgres@database:5432/postgres
pipo-dapp-rollups_indexer-1         | ERROR indexer::data_service: Failed to sync from server manager, details: Tonic status error: Status { code: Aborted, message: "concurrent call in session (already locked by RPC StartSession from ipv4:172.21.0.6:54780 when attempted lock by RPC GetSessionStatus from ipv4:172.21.0.8:34288)", metadata: MetadataMap { headers: {"content-type": "application/grpc"} }, source: None }
```
Any idea what I might be doing wrong? Thanks in advance!

Author: carlofragni
Content: can you provide the full docker compose logs?

Author: p.i.p.o.
Content: Hi Carlo! As there are 7 different containers, I extracted each log separately and compressed them in this file. Please let me know if you prefer them in another way. Thanks for your help!

Author: carlofragni
Content:
From your logs, seems like you had an issue when building your server manager container. Checking the logs of it there is an error "finish_error_yield_none" from the start. 

Since your logs don't have a hardhat container, I'm assuming you are trying to deploy on testnet. When deploying on testnet the 1st thing you should do is build the Cartesi Machine (as its hash is needed for deploying the DApp smart contract). You do this using the `docker buildx bake -f docker-bake.hcl -f docker-bake.override.hcl machine --load` command. Once the machine is built it's time to have the DApp Smart contract created. This is done by defining some environment variables with the parameters to connect to the blockchain, for example:
```
export NETWORK=goerli
export MNEMONIC=<user sequence of twelve words>
export RPC_URL=https://eth-goerli.alchemyapi.io/v2/<USER_KEY>
```
and then using the command to deploy the contract, for example: `DAPP_NAME=pipo docker compose -f ./deploy-testnet.yml up`

At this point the next step is initializing your server manager container. When you initialize the server manager container, it boots the Cartesi Machine and provides a special input as the 1st input ever. This input contains the address of the own DApp, you should handle this in a way that makes sense to your application (store on a database, file, hashmap, etc) as you'll need it to validate inputs coming from the portal, for instance. After handling it, it's expected for your application to yield (by calling the /finish HTTP endpoint). The error you are getting suggests me that during this initialization process, your application did not successfully yield, probably because it crashed. Do take a look at the server manager initialization output as it prints the output of the Cartesi Machine booting and also the outcome (cartesi machine yield).

Author: p.i.p.o.
Content: Thanks! I'll take a look and let you know what happened

Author: p.i.p.o.
Content:

I've seen this error before when trying to run the same command. Eventually, it passed. Is it possible to modify the gas_limit parameter from my side. Could this crash affect the execution of the remaining steps? 
The cartesi machine container (pipo-dapp-machine-1) runs successfully.

Author: carlofragni
Content: It's common to get that error if the 1st account of the wallet specified in the MNEMONIC environment variable doesn't have enough funds to deploy the contract.

Author: p.i.p.o.
Content:
Sorry for not being clear in my first post about the deployment on testnet! I just realized.

I have gone through the README.md step by step, but at no point does it talk about building the server manager container. At least not separately. Is it not built when I run the validator node with the command 
`DAPP_NAME=<example> docker compose -f ../docker-compose-testnet.yml -f ./docker-compose.override.yml up`? At least on the docker desktop, there is a container called server_manager-1. This is the container with the `concurrent call in session` error, apparently because of some RPC lock related issue. Another thing I realized is that the dispatcher container continuously restarts. It logs a "start session request failed" with a deadline exceeded msg. I think that is the server-manager container that also causes this...

Content:
Can you send us the log of the cartesi machine creation? `docker buildx bake machine --load`
Also the deploy log? `DAPP_NAME=pipo docker compose -f ./deploy-testnet.yml up`

Content: Also, sorry, my message had an error on the last part, you build the server manager in the 1st step, in the 3rd step you just initialize it when bringing the Cartesi node up.

Author: bigchickenwin
Content: It's better not posting any suspicious zip file here or suggest others to download. It's not safe practice.

Author: p.i.p.o.
Content: Hi Carlo, I was finally able to find out what the problem was. After doing a research of everything I could think of, I found that the problem is in the step when running the validator node of the dapp. I was using a MacBook Pro with M1 chip last week and I had no crashes due to this, just the logs I sent you. But then, what I did notice were some alerts/warnings in docker when running the validator with the AMD64 caption. I was investigating, and although there was nothing too suspicious, I finally decided to start all over again with a Linux laptop (Lenovo E495 Ubuntu 20.04LTS). It turned out that everything worked as expected and I was able to deploy, run the validator node and interact with the dapp from the frontend-cli. At some point, this AMD64 architecture conflict with the M1 is playing a dark role when running docker containers. I hope it can be useful for M1 users!

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
We've got developer docs to walk you through the steps for installing and building DApps with Cartesi here https://docs.cartesi.io/
One of our main product is Cartesi Rollups that uses Cartesi Machine for running the logic of the DApps in a deterministic and decentralized manner. The Cartesi Machine provides you a Linux runtime that you can leverage to build decentralized applications using the languages and libraries that you already know like Python, Rust, C++ etc. Once you start going through the docs I hope you understand it better. In case you feel stuck or face any doubts, do post them here!

Author: riseandshaheen
Content: Also, I'd recommend a workshop video here https://youtu.be/pbLhHbOc-m0 to get an overview on what, why and how to build with Cartesi!

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
Not really! Production mode means that your backend code(here echo.js example)  runs inside the Cartesi Machine. Here's more on it https://docs.cartesi.io/build-dapps/overview/#production-mode
In quick start page, below is the command that'd build the prod mode backend for you:
```
docker buildx bake --load
```
After this, you spin up your prod mode docker environment and use frontend-console application to interact with it. `yarn build` is to build that frontend console app. It remains same irrespective of host or prod mode.
Did you face any errors in the Quick Start page? Please specify that line for me to check! This page only deals with production mode.

Author: lyorrei
Content:
I'm a full stack developer, with lots of experience with web3, solidity, ethers, etc and am looking to get into Cartesi
Can you answer me some questions?
I'll go by parts, increasing the complexity as I understand
first, assuming I want to write an erc20 contract and mint X amount of coins to a wallet that is coming from a frontend through metamask, how do I do this with cartesi?
Secondly, how do I retrieve how many coins a wallet has?
Thank you in advance

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
Okay so, Cartesi is a rollup solution that means you can port assets(like erc20) from base layer ethereum to your rollup dApp. You can create a mintable erc20 contract on Ethereum and use the same contract coupled with your application logic inside Cartesi rollup. You can retrieve the coins of a dApp wallet by an `inspect` api call to the cartesi machine, it can generate a `report` stating the balance of the wallet in question. This will be a part of your application logic and you'll have to define it.
Let me see if I can find an example to your specific case but for starters here's a basic erc20 example that you can refer https://github.com/cartesi/rollups-examples/tree/main/erc20

Author: lyorrei
Content:
Thank you for your answer Shaheen!
So that means that I still have to write a solidity contract and deploy it on the mainnet, but I can refer to it inside the Cartesi Machine and execute more complex algorithms right? For example, I can run an AI that returns how many coins should be minted based on an input that is coming from a frontend. Can you confirm me that?
Other question, how can I execute the mint function of an ERC20 contract deployed in the mainnet from the cartesi machine?

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
Yeah, you refer to the contract on chain and execute more complex algorithms inside the cartesi machine. I'm not aware of the whole application that you're building, but what you mentioned can be possibly achieved.
For the mint functionality, on-chain part, I believe the erc20 contract in question should be "mintable" type and you'll have to give minting rights to the rollup dapp address. Inside the Cartesi rollup backend of your dApp, you'll process the input with the AI/ML logic and then you'll have to make a `voucher` api call that will target our erc20 contract with payload as per your requirement. 
Here's this auction dapp that has some features that will def help you. It has a basic wallet implemented for you to deposit, withdraw, transfer and get balance. https://github.com/cartesi/rollups-examples/tree/main/auction

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
Which docker command did you use to spin up the node? @Lyo | Inteli Blockchain
I think it's not picking up the correct host server-manager docker image referenced in `docker-compose-host.yml` file. Could you turn down the containers and remove the volume by:
```
docker compose down -v
```
And then spin it up again using:
```
docker compose -f docker-compose.yml -f docker-compose.override.yml -f docker-compose-host.yml up
```
then run your local server again:
```
ROLLUP_HTTP_SERVER_URL="http://127.0.0.1:5004" python3 your-dapp.py
```

Author: lyorrei
Content: Is there any way that I can send an Image to the backend? I was thinking maybe using the Input Contract and sending the image bytecode so that I can access that inside the backend. This is important so that I can use the image as an input of an AI model that is running in the backend.

Author: lyorrei
Content: Or is there any other way that I can send it directly?

Author: riseandshaheen
Content: No, there is no direct path. Inputs should be available on-chain. You'll have to use the `addInput` frontend api call that sends input data to the Input contract. Try compressing the image data before sending and then decompress inside your backend logic.

Author: gustavooooooooo
Content: im a beginner and im a bit confused on what cartesi really is

Author: gustavooooooooo
Content: specially about cartesi rollups, cartesi machine, how they relate to eachother

Author: gustavooooooooo
Content: my knowledge on blockchain stuff is still pretty poor too ngl

Author: gustavooooooooo
Content: but could someone explain in simple terms for someone whos not familiar with dapps, smart contracts, solidity?

Author: gustavooooooooo
Content: ive been trying to read the intro but i still dont get it quite well

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
Hey Gustavo! Welcome to the community! 
Cartesi rollups is an infrastructure layer that allows you to run complex dApps without compromising the security of a base layer like Ethereum. This infrastructure has multiple components, for instance handling inputs, outputs, managing assets, dispute resolution etc. At the heart of it lies the Cartesi machine, which is where the core logic(backend) of your dapp runs. You may refer to it as the "execution environment" or the "virtual machine" of the Cartesi rollups. Say you build a game on Cartesi, your on-chain component will fetch the input from the user and the game logic/rules would run inside the Cartesi machine. 
Hope that adds some clarity. I'd suggest to get your hands dirty, build something and each component will unfold in front of you.

Content: @gustavo

Author: lyorrei
Content: Hello guys, can you assist me? I'd like to understand if it's feasible to transfer Ether from my backend running on the Cartesi Machine. I was considering the possibility of the user sending Ether to a contract that Cartesi owns. Later on, when the time comes, the Ether would be transferred from this contract to a specific wallet. Maybe by a voucher transaction. Could you guide me on how to execute this process?

Author: riseandshaheen
Content:
Hey Lyo! Yes, you can deposit and withdraw assets(ether, erc20, erc721 etc) to and from Cartesi dapps.
You can use portal smart contract function `depositEther` to send ether from front-end to the Cartesi DApp. Depending on your back-end logic and conditions to withdraw, you can create a `voucher`.
Please refer to this frontend example dapp, it has multiple features including deposit and withdrawals, will help you to build front-end part. https://github.com/prototyp3-dev/frontend-web-cartesi/blob/54cc41ac3592078197e5d56c528ae4d7db4a7a44/src/Input.tsx#L68

For back-end you may refer to this https://github.com/prototyp3-dev/echo-plus/blob/main/dapp/echo-plus.py There are no special conditions to voucher creation, it simply transfers the assets back to the depositor hence the name "echo". You can modify it. Note: This backend is built on rollups-0.8, so I'd suggest using the correct method names for rollups-0.9. Here's a breaking change guide https://docs.cartesi.io/cartesi-rollups/migration-guides/from-08-to-09/

Content: Thank you so much @Shaheen !
